Comparison of average male and female life expectancy at birth for countries
and territories as defined in the 2013 CIA Factbook, with selected bubbles
labelled. The dotted line corresponds to equal female and male life
expectancy. The apparent 3D volumes of the bubbles are linearly proportional
to their population.[1][2] (In [the SVG
file](http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b2/Comparison_gender_life_expectancy_CIA_factbook.svg),
hover over a bubble to highlight it and show its data.)

This is a collection of lists of countries by average [life
expectancy](/wiki/Life_expectancy "Life expectancy") at birth.

##
Methodology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Methodology")]

Life expectancy equals the average number of years a person born in a given
country is expected to live if mortality rates at each age were to remain
steady in the future. The life expectancy is shown separately for males and
females, as well as a combined figure. Several non-[sovereign
entities](/wiki/Sovereign_state "Sovereign state") are also included in this
list.

The figures reflect the quality of healthcare in the countries listed as well
as other factors including ongoing wars, obesity, and HIV
infections.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Worldwide, the average life expectancy at birth was 71.5 years (68 years and 4
months for males and 72 years and 8 months for females) over the period
2010–2015 according to United Nations World Population Prospects 2015
Revision,[3] or 69 years (67 years for males and 71.1 years for females) for
2016 according to _[The World Factbook](/wiki/The_World_Factbook "The World
Factbook")_.[4] According to the 2015 [World Health
Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization")
(WHO) data, women on average live longer than men in all major regions and in
all individual countries except for [Mali](/wiki/Mali "Mali") and
[Swaziland](/wiki/Swaziland "Swaziland").[3]

The countries with the lowest overall life expectancies per the WHO are Sierra
Leone, the Central African Republic, the [Democratic Republic of the
Congo](/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo "Democratic Republic of the
Congo"), [Guinea-Bissau](/wiki/Guinea-Bissau "Guinea-Bissau"),
[Lesotho](/wiki/Lesotho "Lesotho"), [Somalia](/wiki/Somalia "Somalia"),
[Swaziland](/wiki/Swaziland "Swaziland"), [Angola](/wiki/Angola "Angola"),
[Chad](/wiki/Chad "Chad"), [Mali](/wiki/Mali "Mali"), [Burundi](/wiki/Burundi
"Burundi"), [Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroon "Cameroon"), and
[Mozambique](/wiki/Mozambique "Mozambique"). Of those countries, only Lesotho,
Swaziland, and Mozambique in 2011 were suffering from an [HIV
prevalence](/wiki/HIV_prevalence "HIV prevalence") rate of greater than 10
percent in the 15–49 age group.[5]

Comparing life expectancies from birth across countries can be problematic.
There are differing definitions of live birth vs stillbirth even among more
developed countries and less developed countries often have poor reporting.[6]

[Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan")'s data is not included in the following WHO
statistics. According to the [Ministry of the Interior of
Taiwan](/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_\(Taiwan\) "Ministry of the Interior
\(Taiwan\)"), the life expectancy of the 23.5-million [Taiwanese
people](/wiki/Taiwanese_people "Taiwanese people") reached 80.2 years in 2015,
up from 79.84 years in 2014. The life expectancy of Taiwanese males averaged
77.01, while that of females reached 83.62, both of which were record
highs.[7]

[Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong") is a territory with the world's
highest life expectancy according to [Hong Kong Department of
Health](/wiki/Department_of_Health_\(Hong_Kong\) "Department of Health \(Hong
Kong\)"), the life expectancy reached 84.0 years in 2015 surpassing
[Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan")'s 83.7 years. With men at 81.2 years and women at
87.3 years. The data is not included in the following WHO statistics as a
separate entity since [Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong") is a [Special
Administrative Region](/wiki/Special_administrative_regions_of_China "Special
administrative regions of China") of China, and is not itself a member of the
WHO.[8]

Economic and Social
Affairs](/wiki/United_Nations_Department_of_Economic_and_Social_Affairs
"United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs") (UN DESA),
released _World Population Prospects, The 2015 Revision_.[3] The following
table shows the life expectancy at birth for the period 2010 to 2015.

## List from the "GBD 2010"
study[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: List from the "GBD 2010" study")]

The Global Burden of Disease 2010 study published updated figures in 2012,[12]
including recalculations of life expectancies[13] which differ substantially
in places from the UN estimates for 2010 (reasons for this are discussed in
the freely available appendix to the paper, pages 25–27, currently not
available). Although no estimate is given for the sexes combined, for the
first time life expectancy estimates have included uncertainty intervals.

Factbook") 2009[1] and from the 2010 revision of the United Nations World
Population Prospects report, for 2005–2010,[3] (data viewable at
<http://esa.un.org/wpp/Sorting-Tables/tab-sorting_mortality.htm>, with
equivalent spreadsheets [here](http://esa.un.org/wpp/Excel-
Data/DB01_Period_Indicators/WPP2010_DB1_F05_3_LIFE_EXPECTANCY_0_FEMALE.XLS),
[here](http://esa.un.org/wpp/Excel-
Data/DB01_Period_Indicators/WPP2010_DB1_F05_2_LIFE_EXPECTANCY_0_MALE.XLS), and
[here](http://esa.un.org/wpp/Excel-
Data/DB01_Period_Indicators/WPP2010_DB1_F05_1_LIFE_EXPECTANCY_0_BOTH_SEXES.XLS)).

Only countries/territories with a population of 100,000 or more in 2010 are
included in the United Nations list. WHO database 2013
<http://www.who.int/gho/publications/world_health_statistics/EN_WHS2013_Full.pdf>
